pageData.text: Simple harmonic motion is a type of that is described as the back-and-forth motion of an object as it passes through an equilibrium or mean position. In the absence of , an object could be in oscillatory motion continually. However, in the real world, this is not possible, and the object will eventually come to rest at its . The object’s equilibrium position is the location where it experiences no linear or angular . Simple harmonic motion is defined as any motion where a restoring force is applied that is proportional to the and acts in the opposite direction of that displacement. The , a mass on a string, exhibits simple harmonic motion and is examined in this lab to determine the dependence of mass, , and length of the string on the of the pendulum.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 15 minutes 
Activity 1: Exploring Simple Harmonic Motion Varying the Mass of the Pendulum Bob – 20 minutes 
                 Varying the Angular Displacement of the Pendulum Bob – 20 minutes 
                 Varying the Length of the Simple Pendulum – 20 minutes 
Activity 2: Data Analysis – 20 minutes 
Extension Activity 1 – 60 minutes

pageData.text: A consists of a mass, called a bob, on a string. Typically, the bob is raised to a given angle, released, and the bob moves over an arc through the air, experiencing periodic motion. In some places in the world, you can act as the bob of the pendulum on gigantic swings. These swings, like the Nevis Swing in New Zealand, typically release the swinger from horizontal on a platform on one side of a canyon or other open area and allow them to move through the air while attached to a harness. The harness and ropes are attached to a pivot point that acts as the attachment of the giant pendulum. As the bob of the pendulum, the swinger moves through the air at high speed in an arc the length of the ropes attached to their pivot. In an idealized system, they would return to the exact same height at the other side, but, because of air resistance and , the swinger will likely return to a slightly lower height than horizontal. If the swinger goes back and forth multiple times, the height of the swinger over time would look like a sine wave, just like that of the bob of a pendulum.

pageData.altText: A large swing over a canyon where humans act as the bob of a pendulum.

pageData.subTitle: Simple Harmonic Motion
pageData.text: is defined as the back-and-forth motion of an object as it passes through an equilibrium or mean position. In the absence of , an object could be in oscillatory motion continually. However, in the real world, this is not possible, and the object will eventually come to rest at its . The object’s equilibrium position is the location where it experiences no linear or angular . Examples of oscillatory motion include the movement of a spring, vibration of strings on a musical instrument, water waves, and a (Figure 1).

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A simple pendulum consisting of a mass, called the bob, at the bottom end of a length of string, called the arm, which is anchored at the top end at the pivot.
pageData.desc: Figure 1: A simple pendulum consisting of a mass, called the bob, at the bottom end of a length of string, called the arm, which is anchored at the top end at the pivot.

pageData.text: is one type of oscillatory motion in which the , , and acceleration vary with respect to time as either a sine or a cosine function. A mass attached to a light, non-stretchable string and suspended from a fixed support is called a simple pendulum. The motion of the mass of the simple pendulum represents SHM. The mass of the simple pendulum experiences a restoring force that is directly proportional to the displacement, x, of the mass from its equilibrium position, as shown in Equation 1.

pageData.altText: Equation 1: F equals negative k x
pageData.desc: Equation 1: F equals negative k x

pageData.text: The proportionality constant is k, and the direction of the restoring force is toward the equilibrium position. The acceleration of the mass is proportional to the displacement, x, from equilibrium and the , ω, of the mass, given by the relationship of Equation 2.

pageData.altText: Equation 2: equation vector a equals negative omega squared times x
pageData.desc: Equation 2: equation vector a equals negative omega squared times x

pageData.text: The time it takes the mass to make one complete oscillation is called the , T, described as the movement of the mass from the maximum from equilibrium at the beginning of the swing, through the , to the maximum displacement from equilibrium on the other side of the swing, back through equilibrium, and returning to its starting location. The period is measured in units of time (seconds) and is inversely related to the , ω, as shown in Equation 3.

pageData.altText: Equation 3: T equals begin fraction 2 pi over omega end fraction
pageData.desc: Equation 3: T equals begin fraction 2 pi over omega end fraction

pageData.text: The reciprocal of the period is the (Equation 4), which measures the number of oscillations per unit time in hertz (cycles per second or oscillations per second).

pageData.altText: Equation 4: f equals begin fraction 1 over T end fraction
pageData.desc: Equation 4: f equals begin fraction 1 over T end fraction

pageData.text: Both period and frequency are related to angular , ω, as shown in Equation 5.

pageData.altText: Equation 5: omega equals 2 pi f equals begin fraction 2 pi over T end fraction
pageData.desc: Equation 5: omega equals 2 pi f equals begin fraction 2 pi over T end fraction

pageData.subTitle: The Simple Pendulum
pageData.text: A simple pendulum consists of a small object (the pendulum bob) suspended from the end of a lightweight cord (see Figure 2). It is assumed the cord does not stretch and that its mass can be ignored relative to mass of the pendulum bob. The swinging back-and-forth motion of the pendulum bob with negligible <button class='glossary-text'>friction</button> resembles simple harmonic motion: the pendulum bob oscillates through the arc of a circle with equal <button class='glossary-text'>amplitude</button> on either side of the equilibrium point. The pendulum bob has its maximum speed passing through the equilibrium point, where the pendulum hangs vertically when not in motion. To be undergoing simple harmonic motion, the restoring force must be proportional to its displacement.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: A pendulum bob labeled with the angle, length, and equations as described in the text
pageData.desc: Figure 2: A pendulum bob labeled with the angle, length, and equations as described in the text

pageData.text: The s of the pendulum along the arc is s = Lθ, where θ is the angle (measured in radians), the cord makes the vertical, and L is the length of the cord, as illustrated in the . The restoring force is the net force on the bob, which equals the component of the weight tangent to the arc, shown in Equation 6. The weight of the pendulum bob is mass, m, times the due to gravity, g, or mg.

pageData.altText: Equation 6: F equals negative m g sine theta
pageData.desc: Equation 6: F equals negative m g sine theta

pageData.text: The minus sign means the direction of the force is opposite to the θ. With F being proportional to the sinθ rather than to θ, the motion is not by definition simple harmonic motion, restoring force proportional to displacement. However, if θ is small, then sinθ is very nearly θ (measured in radians). This can be seen in the series expansion of sinθ, Equation 7, as well as reviewing , noting the arc length, s = Lθ, is nearly equal to the length as the cord = Lsinθ (shown by the red horizontal straight line).

pageData.altText: Equation 7: sine theta equals sigma sup infinity sub n equals sub 0 begin paren minus 1 end paren sup n begin fraction theta sup 2 sup n plus sup 1 over begin paren 2 n plus 1 end paren factorial end fraction equals theta minus begin fraction theta sup 3 over 3 factorial end fraction plus begin fraction theta sup 5 over 5 factorial end fraction minus begin fraction theta sup 7 over 7 factorial end fraction plus elipses
pageData.desc: Equation 7: sine theta equals sigma sup infinity sub n equals sub 0 begin paren minus 1 end paren sup n begin fraction theta sup 2 sup n plus sup 1 over begin paren 2 n plus 1 end paren factorial end fraction equals theta minus begin fraction theta sup 3 over 3 factorial end fraction plus begin fraction theta sup 5 over 5 factorial end fraction minus begin fraction theta sup 7 over 7 factorial end fraction plus elipses

pageData.text: Valid for θ Є ℝ all (Real Numbers)
If θ is small, less than 15 degrees, the difference between θ (in radians) and sinθ is less than 1 percent and the restoring force becomes the relationship in Equation 8.

pageData.altText: Equation 8: F equals negative m g sine theta approximately equal to negative m g theta
pageData.desc: Equation 8: F equals negative m g sine theta approximately equal to negative m g theta

pageData.text: Substituting for θ using s = Lθ or θ = s/L gives Equation 9.

pageData.altText: Equation 9: F equals negative begin fraction m g s over L end fraction
pageData.desc: Equation 9: F equals negative begin fraction m g s over L end fraction

pageData.text: Then for small displacements, the motion of the pendulum bob is approximately simple harmonic, following the relationship F = −kx. The arc length s replaces x, and the effective force constant k = mg/L.
The angular displacement can be written as Equation 10.

pageData.altText: Equation 10: theta equals theta sub max cosine begin paren omega t plus phi close paren
pageData.desc: Equation 10: theta equals theta sub max cosine begin paren omega t plus phi close paren

pageData.text: θmax is the maximum , and ω is the angular equal to 2πf or 2π/T. (f is the frequency in cycles per second, and T is the in seconds.) To derive the expression for force constant km, use Newton’s second law and the relationship:

pageData.altText: sigma F equals m a

pageData.text: Substitute for F = –kx and the definition for a.

pageData.altText: Negative k x equals m begin fraction d sup 2 x over d sup 2 t end fraction right arrow begin fraction k x over m end fraction plus begin fraction d sup 2 x over d sup 2 t end fraction equals 0

pageData.text: If x = A cos(ωt + φ), then
k /m A cos(ωt + φ) - ω2 A cos(ωt + φ) = 0
Solve for ω2.

pageData.altText: Equation 11: omega sup 2 equals begin fraction k over m end fraction right arrow omega equals begin square root begin fraction k over m end fraction end square root
pageData.desc: Equation 11: omega sup 2 equals begin fraction k over m end fraction right arrow omega equals begin square root begin fraction k over m end fraction end square root

pageData.text: The relationship of Equation 11 can then be used to find ω for the by substituting into the relationship the effective k for the pendulum mg/L.

pageData.altText: Equation 12: omega equals begin square root begin fraction k over m end fraction end square root equals begin square root begin fraction begin fraction m g over L end fraction over m end fraction end square root equals begin square root begin fraction g over L end fraction end square root
pageData.desc: Equation 12: omega equals begin square root begin fraction k over m end fraction end square root equals begin square root begin fraction begin fraction m g over L end fraction over m end fraction end square root equals begin square root begin fraction g over L end fraction end square root

pageData.text: The frequency of the pendulum is:

pageData.altText: Equation 13: 2 pi f equals begin square root begin fraction g over L end fraction end square root right arrow f equals begin fraction 1 over 2 pi end fraction begin square root begin fraction g over L end fraction end square root
pageData.desc: Equation 13: 2 pi f equals begin square root begin fraction g over L end fraction end square root right arrow f equals begin fraction 1 over 2 pi end fraction begin square root begin fraction g over L end fraction end square root

pageData.text: The period of the pendulum is:

pageData.altText: Equation 14: Begin fraction 2 pi over T end fraction equals begin square root begin fraction g over L end fraction end square root right arrow T equals 2 pi begin square root begin fraction L over g end fraction end square root
pageData.desc: Equation 14: Begin fraction 2 pi over T end fraction equals begin square root begin fraction g over L end fraction end square root right arrow T equals 2 pi begin square root begin fraction L over g end fraction end square root

pageData.text: The mass, m, of the pendulum bob does not appear in the equations for f and T. Therefore, the and for a do not depend on the mass of the pendulum bob. These relationships also show the frequency and period of the pendulum do not depend on the if the amplitude, θ, is small.

From the relationship of , you can see that in the presence of constant due to gravity, g, the period of a simple pendulum depends only on the length, L, of the pendulum. The period does not depend on the mass of the pendulum bob, and the period does not depend on the pendulum’s , θ, for small angles.

The simple pendulum, a mass on a string, exhibits simple harmonic motion and is examined in this lab to determine the dependence of mass, angular , and length of the string on the period of the pendulum.

pageData.question: A mass is placed at the end of a string. The mass oscillates at an initial velocity of v. If the initial velocity of the mass increases to 2v, what would be the new period of oscillation?

options.text: The new period would remain the same.
The new period would be half as long.
The new period would be twice as long.
The new period would be four times as long.
The new period would be the square root of the initial period.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The period of a pendulum only depends on the length of the pendulum and the acceleration due to gravity, g.

pageData.question: A man swings a bucket of water back and forth at the end of a rope, creating a pendulum.  Which of the following actions would increase the period of the pendulum?

options.text: Increase the length of the rope.
Remove the water from the bucket.
Swing the bucket from a greater height.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Increasing the length of the rope will increase the period of the pendulum.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
The period of the pendulum is:
The mass, m, of the pendulum bob does not appear in the equations for f and T. Therefore, the frequency and period for a simple pendulum do not depend on the mass of the pendulum bob. These relationships also show the frequency and period of the pendulum do not depend on the amplitude if the amplitude, θ, is small. From the relationship of Equation 14, you can see that in the presence of constant acceleration due to gravity, g, the period of a simple pendulum depends only on the length, L, of the pendulum. The period does not depend on the mass of the pendulum bob, and the period does not depend on the pendulum’s angular displacement, θ, for small angles.

img.alt: Equation 14: Begin fraction 2 pi over T end fraction equals begin square root begin fraction g over L end fraction end square root right arrow T equals 2 pi begin square root begin fraction L over g end fraction end square root

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
The period of the pendulum is:
The mass, m, of the pendulum bob does not appear in the equations for f and T. Therefore, the frequency and period for a simple pendulum do not depend on the mass of the pendulum bob. These relationships also show the frequency and period of the pendulum do not depend on the amplitude if the amplitude, θ, is small. From the relationship of Equation 14, you can see that in the presence of constant acceleration due to gravity, g, the period of a simple pendulum depends only on the length, L, of the pendulum. The period does not depend on the mass of the pendulum bob, and the period does not depend on the pendulum’s angular displacement, θ, for small angles.

img.alt: Equation 14: Begin fraction 2 pi over T end fraction equals begin square root begin fraction g over L end fraction end square root right arrow T equals 2 pi begin square root begin fraction L over g end fraction end square root

pageData.subTitle: Energy of the Simple Pendulum
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Mechanical energy</button>—potential and <button class='glossary-text'>kinetic energy</button>—will be conserved for the <button class='glossary-text'>simple pendulum</button> in the absence of <button class='glossary-text'>friction</button> or air resistance. The total mechanical energy equal to the <button class='glossary-text'>gravitational potential energy</button> and kinetic energy will remain constant throughout the swing of the pendulum bob with the continual transfer of energy between gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy.
The gravitational potential energy, U, of the pendulum bob is calculated using Equation 15 and is a scalar quantity measured in units of J, Joules.

pageData.altText: Equation 15: Gravitational Potential Energy, U equals m g h
pageData.desc: Equation 15: Gravitational Potential Energy, U equals m g h

pageData.text: The mass of the pendulum bob is m, the due to gravity is g, and the height the pendulum bob is raised above the (bottom of the swing) is h. The height, h, is determined from the length, L, of the pendulum and the angle the pendulum bob is displaced from the vertical (see Figure 3).

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Pendulum with bob displaced from the vertical and labeled with the length, height, angle theta sub max, L cosine theta sub max
pageData.desc: Figure 3: Pendulum with bob displaced from the vertical and labeled with the length, height, angle theta sub max, L cosine theta sub max

pageData.text: Using the parameters of θ, the , and L, pendulum length, as shown in , the height, h, is determined as shown in Equation 16.

pageData.altText: Equation 16: h equals L begin paren 1 minus cosine theta close paren
pageData.desc: Equation 16: h equals L begin paren 1 minus cosine theta close paren

pageData.text: Substituting this relationship for h into the , U, equation () gives the gravitational potential energy at any angle during the pendulum’s motion, as shown in Equation 17.

pageData.altText: Equation 17: U equals m g L begin paren 1 minus cosine theta close paren
pageData.desc: Equation 17: U equals m g L begin paren 1 minus cosine theta close paren

pageData.text: The relationship for calculating , KE, is shown in Equation 18, where m is the mass of the pendulum bob and v is the linear of the pendulum bob. Kinetic energy is a scalar quantity with units of J, Joules.

pageData.altText: Equation 18: Kinetic Energy, K E equals Begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction m v sup 2
pageData.desc: Equation 18: Kinetic Energy, K E equals Begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction m v sup 2

pageData.text: Before the pendulum starts in motion, the kinetic energy is zero. As the pendulum begins moving, gravitational potential energy is transferred to kinetic energy and the linear velocity of the pendulum bob increases. At the bottom of the pendulum swing, the linear velocity and kinetic energy are maximum; the gravitational potential energy goes to zero (h = 0). The pendulum bob continues its swing moving upward on the opposite side from the start of the swing. The velocity decreases to zero when the kinetic energy has been transferred to gravitational potential energy and the pendulum bob is the same height, h, above the (in the absence of ). The process then repeats as the pendulum bob swings back and forth. The total at any point along the swing is the sum of the gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy as shown in Equation 19.

pageData.altText: Equation 19: E sub Total equals K E plus U equals Constant
pageData.desc: Equation 19: E sub Total equals K E plus U equals Constant

pageData.text: The energy relationships of a <button class='glossary-text'>simple pendulum</button> are examined in the lab’s extension activity.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of activity one of this investigation. To prepare, clear an area for the pendulum, measure the mass of washers and pendulum, assemble and hang the pendulum and measure its length. In activity 1, displace the pendulum by a given angle, record the pendulum swing and determine the time for 5 oscillations. Next, calculate the period of oscillation. Then, add a washer and repeat for 1-4 washers. Next, reset the pendulum, record its mass and displace the pendulum by the specified angle. Then, record the pendulum swing, determine the time for 5 oscillations and calculate the period of. Next, change the angle of displacement and repeat for all angles. Then, reset the pendulum, record the mass and displace the pendulum by the given angle. Next, record the pendulum swing, determine the time for 5 oscillations and calculate the period. Then, change the length of the pendulum and repeat for all lengths. Proceed to Activity 2.

A map of the procedural workflow for activity 2 and extension activity of this investigation. After completing activity 1, in activity 2, you will calculate the period of oscillation using the given equation, calculate the percent difference in periods and calculate the square root of L for the length trials.  Then, you will graph period versus square root of L. In the extension activity, you will open the PHET activity “Masses and Springs” and set up the spring with given conditions. Then, you will run the simulation and determine the time for 5 oscillations. Next, you will vary the conditions and repeat the trials for all of the given conditions. Then, you will calculate the period of the spring for each trial, the angular frequency, the average angular frequency and the spring constant. Finally, you will calculate the potential and kinetic energy of the spring that the given points.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Simple Harmonic Motion investigation (item number 580261) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company. Call: 866.332.4478 to order.

pageData.altText: goggles symbol

pageData.text: Wear your safety goggles at all times while conducting this investigation. Read all the instructions for this activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment.
Take precautions reaching the high place, such as a ceiling or top of a doorway, when hanging your pendulum. Be careful accessing this place; you may need to stand on a step stool or sturdy chair.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this investigation. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after the investigation, and clean the work area with soap and water after finishing. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: A pendulum in simple harmonic motion has the greatest speed at which of the following points in the path of the pendulum bob?

options.text: between the equilibrium point and either end of its path

assestmentData.question: A pendulum in simple harmonic motion has the greatest acceleration at which of the following points in the path of the pendulum?

options.text: between the equilibrium point and either end of its path

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes simple harmonic motion?

options.text: Any motion where a restoring force is applied that is proportional to the displacement and acts in the opposite direction of that displacement.
Any motion where a restoring force is applied that is inversely proportional to the displacement and acts in the same direction as that displacement.
Any motion where a restoring force is applied that is proportional to the displacement and acts in the same direction as that displacement.
Any motion where a restoring force is applied that is opposite value of the displacement and acts in the same direction as that displacement.
Any motion where a restoring force is applied that is inversely proportional to the displacement and acts in the opposite direction of that displacement.

assestmentData.question: A length of string and a 1.50 kg mass are used to create a simple pendulum.  When the pendulum is displaced from equilibrium and released from rest, it is observed that the period of the pendulum is 5.80 seconds.  What is the length of the string?  Assume g = 9.8 m/s<sup>2</sup>.

A 0.540 kg mass is used to create a simple pendulum with a length of 2.00 meters.  If the pendulum is displaced from equilibrium and released from rest, what is the period of the pendulum?  Assume g = 9.8 m/s<sup>2</sup>.
A grandfather clock’s pendulum has a length of 1.25 meters.  If the clock loses 30 seconds per day, how should the pendulum be adjusted?

options.text: increase the mass of the pendulum bob
decrease the mass of the pendulum bob
increase the pendulum length and increase the mass of the bob

assestmentData.question: A simple pendulum has a period of 1.875 seconds on Earth.  What would the period of the pendulum be on Mars where the acceleration due to gravity is 3.721 m/s<sup>2</sup>?

A simple pendulum with a length of 1.5 meters is displaced 30.0 degrees from its equilibrium position.  If the mass of the pendulum bob is 0.0655 kg, what is the pendulum’s gravitational potential energy as it is released?  Assume g = 9.8 m/s<sup>2</sup>.

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the procedure.
Watch the following video on camera recording techniques for physics investigations:

pageData.desc: Camera recording techniques for physics

pageData.text: Create a work space. Determine a suitable location where you can affix a string to a ceiling, doorway, or other location approximately 2 meters above the floor to construct your pendulum (without damaging the area). If permitted where you live, you can use a pushpin, tack, or a place where a hook for a light or decoration exists. The pendulum needs to swing freely without contacting objects in the area.
Fashion a mass hanger out of one of the paper clips. A second paper clip mass hanger may be needed as additional mass is added to the pendulum bob.

Determine the mass of each of the 4 washers. Record these values in Data Table 1 in the Lab Notebook. If all the washers do not have the same mass, you will need to keep track of the washers and their masses.
Place 1 large washer on the paper clip hanger. Record the mass of this washer in Data Table 2 as the mass of the pendulum bob for the 1 washer trial.
Tie a loop at one end of the string, and attach the paper clip hanger with a large washer to the loop.

Tie a loop at the other end of the string so you have a with an initial length, L, of ~1.5 meters (or as close as you can get to 1.5 meters). Measure the length of the pendulum from the pivot point to the center of mass of the pendulum bob (the washer). The ~1.5 meters will include the distance from your top loop, the length of the paper clip hanger, plus the radius of the washer at the other end.
Attach the simple pendulum to the ceiling (or other high place). Take precautions, and use a sturdy step stool or chair.

With the pendulum in place, measure the length (from pivot point to the center of the large washer). When measuring, the string should be pulled tight by the pendulum bob (washer). Record this value as the constant pendulum length in Data Table 2.
Allow the pendulum bob to hang straight down—the .

pageData.altText: goggles symbol
pageData.text: Before setting the pendulum in motion to start timing measurements, put on your safety goggles.
In Activity 1, you will construct a pendulum and use it to measure the effect of pendulum mass, angle of and length of pendulum on the of oscillation. You will analyze the data in Activity 2.

typeBefore.text: Note: Record measurements and make calculations using SI units with the correct number of significant digits.

typeBefore.title:
A
 Varying the Mass of the Pendulum Bob (12 steps)

typeBefore.text: For Part A, you will change the mass of the pendulum bob by changing the number of washers attached to your paper clip hanger while keeping the <button class='glossary-text'>angular displacement</button> and length of the <button class='glossary-text'>simple pendulum</button> constant.

pageData.text: If you will not be using a video to time the motion of the simple pendulum, take a picture of your apparatus. Include this image in the Lab Notebook.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Using the protractor, displace your pendulum 30.0 degrees from the equilibrium (vertical position) as shown in Figure 4. Record this angle as the constant angular value in Data Table 2.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: a pendulum from equilibrium with the pivot, arm, and bob labeled, and a pendulum showing the angle relative to the pendulum at rest
pageData.desc: Figure 4: a pendulum from equilibrium with the pivot, arm, and bob labeled, and a pendulum showing the angle relative to the pendulum at rest

pageData.text: Begin videoing or timing as you release the pendulum bob, allowing it to swing back and forth.

Time the motion of the pendulum bob long enough to have 5 complete oscillations. For a complete oscillation, the pendulum must return to the starting location. (The pendulum bob swings down from the starting location through the , continues up to the opposite side momentarily stopping, and then swings back down through the equilibrium position continuing up to the starting location.)
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Play back your video to determine the time or obtain the time from your timing device for 5 complete oscillations of the pendulum bob. Record this value in Data Table 2 for the 1 washer trial.

Determine the , T, of the pendulum by dividing the time for 5 complete oscillations by 5. Record this value in Data Table 2. Check your period for accuracy. If it is not in agreement with , you should repeat the trial.
Attach another washer to the paper clip hanger of your pendulum. Record the total mass of the 2 washers as the mass of the pendulum bob in Data Table 2 for the 2 washers trial.
Repeat Steps 2 through 7 for the 2 washers trial.

Attach another washer to the paper clip hanger of your pendulum. Record the total mass of the 3 washers as the mass of the pendulum bob in Data Table 2 for the 3 washers trial. Use an additional paper clip mass hanger if needed.
Repeat Steps 2 through 7 for the 3 washers trial.

Attach another washer to the paper clip hanger of your pendulum. Record the total mass of the 4 washers as the mass of the pendulum bob in Data Table 2 for the 4 washers trial. Use an additional paper clip hanger if needed.
Repeat Steps 2 through 7 for the 4 washers trial.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>

typeBefore.title:
B
 Varying the Angular Displacement of the Pendulum Bob (13 steps)

typeBefore.text: For Part B, you will change the angular displacement of the simple pendulum while keeping the mass of the pendulum bob (number of washers attached to the paper clip hanger) and length of the simple pendulum constant.

pageData.text: Remove 2 washers from the paper clip hanger. Record the total mass of the two washers remaining on the paper clip hanger as the constant pendulum bob mass in Data Table 3.

Allow the pendulum to hang in the equilibrium position. Measure the length of the pendulum from the pivot at the top to the center of mass (geometric center) of the washers. Record this measurement as the constant pendulum length in Data Table 3. (Since strings tend to stretch, it is good experimental practice to remeasure the string length.)

Using the protractor, displace your pendulum 45.0 degrees from the equilibrium (vertical position) as shown in Figure 4. Record this angle as the angular displacement for the Angle 1 trial in Data Table 3.
Begin videoing or timing as you release the pendulum bob, allowing it to swing back and forth.

Time the motion of the pendulum bob long enough to have 5 complete oscillations. For a complete oscillation, the pendulum must return to the starting location. (The pendulum bob swings down from the starting location through the equilibrium position, continues up to the opposite side momentarily stopping, and then swings back down through the equilibrium position continuing up to the starting location.)
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Play back your video to determine the time, or obtain the time from your timing device for 5 complete oscillations of the pendulum bob. Record this value in Data Table 3 for the Angle 1 trial.

Determine the period, T, of the pendulum by dividing the time for 5 complete oscillations by 5. Record this value in Data Table 3. Check your period for accuracy. If it is not in agreement with Equation 14, you should repeat the trial.

Using the protractor, displace your pendulum 30.0 degrees from the equilibrium (vertical position) as shown in Figure 4. Record this angle as the angular displacement for the Angle 2 trial in Data Table 3. (You can transfer the data for the 2 washers trial of Data Table 2 only if the length of your pendulum is the same.)
Repeat Steps 4 through 7 for the Angle 2 trial.

Using the protractor, displace your pendulum 20.0 degree from the equilibrium (vertical position) as shown in Figure 4. Record this angle as the angular displacement for the Angle 3 trial in Data Table 3.
Repeat Steps 4 through 7 for the Angle 3 trial.

Using the protractor, displace your pendulum 10.0 degrees from the equilibrium (vertical position) as shown in Figure 4. Record this angle as the angular displacement for Angle 4 trial in Data Table 3.
Repeat Steps 4 through 7 for the Angle 4 trial.

typeBefore.title:
C
 Varying the Length of the Simple Pendulum (19 steps)

typeBefore.text: For Part C, you will change the length of the simple pendulum while keeping the mass of the pendulum bob (number of washers attached to the paper clip hanger) and the angular displacement of the simple pendulum constant.

pageData.text: Record the total mass of the two washers on the paper clip hanger as the constant pendulum bob mass in Data Table 4.

Allow the pendulum to hang in the equilibrium position. Measure the length of the pendulum from pivot to center of mass (geometric center) of the washers. Record this as the pendulum length for the first length trial in Data Table 4. (Since strings tend to stretch, it is good experimental practice to remeasure the string length.)
Using the protractor, displace your pendulum 30.0 degrees from the equilibrium (vertical position) as shown in Figure 4. Record this angle as the constant angular displacement in Data Table 4.
Begin videoing or timing as you release the pendulum bob, allowing it to swing back and forth.

Time the motion of the pendulum bob long enough to have 5 complete oscillations. For a complete oscillation, the pendulum must return to the starting location. (The pendulum bob swings down from the starting location through the equilibrium position, continues up to the opposite side momentarily stopping, and then swings back down through the equilibrium position continuing up to the starting location.)
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Play back your video to determine the time or obtain the time from your timing device for 5 complete oscillations of the pendulum bob. Record this value in Data Table 4 for the Length 1 trial. (You can transfer data for a pendulum bob mass of 2 washers displaced at an angle of 30.0 degrees from Data Table 3 only if the length of your pendulum is the same.)

Determine the period, T, of the pendulum by dividing the time for 5 complete oscillations by 5. Record this value in Data Table 4. Check your period for accuracy. If it is not in agreement with Equation 14, you should repeat the trial.

Remove the string from where it is attached and shorten the length of the string by ~25 cm (~0.25 m); get as close to 25 cm as possible. Tie a loop at the end of your shortened string and attach it to the ceiling (or other high place). The length of your pendulum should now be ~1.25 m (or as close as you can get to 1.25 m).

Allow the pendulum to hang in the equilibrium position. Measure the length of your pendulum from the pivot at the top to the center of mass (geometric center) of the washers at the other end. Record this length as the length of the pendulum for the Length 2 trial in Data Table 4.
Using the protractor, displace your pendulum 30.0 degrees from the equilibrium (vertical position) as shown in Figure 4.
Repeat Steps 4 through 7 for the Length 2 trial.

Remove the string from where it is attached and shorten the length of the string by ~25 cm (~0.25 m); get as close to 25 cm as possible. Tie a loop at the end of your shortened string and attach it to the ceiling (or other high place). The length of your pendulum should now be ~1.00 m (or as close as you can get to 1.00 m).

Allow the pendulum to hang in the equilibrium position. Measure the length of your pendulum from the pivot at the top to the center of mass (geometric center) of the washers at the other end. Record this length as the length of the pendulum for the Length 3 trial in Data Table 4.
Using the protractor, displace your pendulum 30.0 degrees from the equilibrium (vertical position) as shown in Figure 4.
Repeat Steps 4 through 7 for the Length 3 trial.

Remove the string from where it is attached and shorten the length of the string by ~25 cm (~0.25 m); get as close to 25 cm as possible. Tie a loop at the end of your shortened string and attach it to the ceiling (or other high place). The length of your pendulum should now be ~0.75 m (or as close as you can get to 0.75 m).

Allow the pendulum to hang in the equilibrium position. Measure the length of your pendulum from the pivot at the top to the center of mass (geometric center) of the washers at the other end. Record this length as the length of the pendulum for the Length 4 trial in Data Table 4.
Using the protractor, displace your pendulum 30.0 degrees from the equilibrium (vertical position) as shown in Figure 4.
Repeat Steps 4 through 7 for the Length 4 trial.

In Activity 2, you will analyze the data from Activity 1 by comparing the experimental and theoretical values for <button class='glossary-text'>period</button> and graphing the relationship between period and square root of pendulum length.

typeBefore.text: Note: Record measurements and make calculations using SI units with the correct number of significant digits.

pageData.text: Calculate the percent error in the periods measured for each trial in Data Table 2. Then record these values in Analysis Data Table for Part I.

pageData.altText: Percent error equals begin brace begin fraction begin paren vertical slash T sub calculated from equation 14 minus T sub measured vertical slash end paren over T sub calculated from equation 14 end fraction end brace times 100

pageData.text: Determine the calculated period of the pendulum using Equation 14 and the pendulum length, L, from Data Table 3. Record this value in Analysis Data Table for Part II.
Calculate the percent error in the periods measured for each trial in Data Table 3. Then record these values in Analysis Data Table for Part II.

pageData.altText: Percent error equals begin brace begin fraction begin paren vertical slash T sub calculated from equation 14 minus T sub measured vertical slash end paren over T sub calculated from equation 14 end fraction end brace times 100

pageData.text: Calculate and record √L for the 4 lengths in Data Table 4.

Use a graphing program, such as Excel or Google Sheets, to create a graph using the data in Data Table 4 of Period, T vs √L. (Note: variables are identified for graphing as y vs x.) On the graph, insert a best-fit line or curve and display the equation. (Title the graph, and label the axes with quantity and units). Consider whether the data point (0, 0) should be included on your graph; include the point (0, 0) if it is in agreement with the experiment and relationships between the variables.

pageData.title: PHeT Masses and Springs Simulation
pageData.text: In the Extension Activity, you will use a simulation of masses on a spring to analyze the effect of mass on the of spring oscillation. You will then calculate the average angular , determine the spring constant, and calculate the kinetic and potential energies for various points on the spring.

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Determine the <button class='glossary-text'>amplitude</button>, period, frequency, and angular frequency for an oscillating mass on a spring.
Determine the spring constant for a spring
Determine <button class='glossary-text'>kinetic energy</button>, elastic potential energy, and total <button class='glossary-text'>mechanical energy</button> for an oscillating mass on a spring.

pageData.title: Background
pageData.text: Most transverse waves can be modeled as sinusoidal waves that depict the oscillation of the medium on the y-axis and the motion of the wave on the x-axis (see Figure E1). A wave’s amplitude or height is the maximum wave (vertical in a transverse wave and horizontal in a longitudinal wave). The distance between two crests or troughs is referred to as wavelength, λ. The time it takes for one complete wave to pass a given point is called a period. The inverse of a wave’s period is its frequency, f. Measured in hertz (Hz), frequency is the number of complete waves that pass a point in one second (Hz = 1/s).

pageData.altText: Figure E1: Diagram of a sinusoidal wave with the amplitude, crest, trough, and wavelength labeled

pageData.text: A wave’s , v, can be determined if the wavelength and frequency are known, v = λf. Wave velocity is also a function of its internal tension, T, and the density of the medium, μ. The density of the medium can be found by dividing the mass of the medium, m, by the length of the medium, L.

Setup the PHeT Masses and Springs simulation with these initial conditions (see Figure E4):

text: Mass = 100 g (Attach the 100 g weight to the spring.)
Spring Constant at midpoint
Check the box by <button class='glossary-text'>Displacement</button>/Natural Length.
Damping—None
Speed (in lower right)—Slow
Pull the timer and ruler out from the small box on the right.
Stretch out the spring. (If you haven’t hit the pause button, the spring should be oscillating.)
Hit the play arrow on the timer to begin timing when the spring is fully extended. (For one complete oscillation, the mass must return to the fully extended position)

pageData.text: When the spring is stretched out with the damping set to None, the <button class='glossary-text'>amplitude</button> should not change.
When you change the mass, the amount the spring is stretched will need to be adjusted: a smaller amount for the 50 g mass and a larger amount for the 200 g mass.

https://phet.colorado.edu

Energy bars: Energy is conserved and the total energy, E, will remain the same. To determine when the values for , K, and potential energy, U, are minimum (0) and maximum, observe the energy bars on the left. Potential energy for a spring: U = (1/2) kx2.

pageData.altText: Figure E5: The lab simulation with the energy bars outlined in red

pageData.text:
Image Credit: Image from PHET simulation used under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 License (“CC BY 4.0”) available at
https://phet.colorado.edu
Take a screenshot of your simulation setup, and include it in the Lab Notebook.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Stretch the spring with the 100 g mass a distance of approximately 30 cm = 0.30 m from the . This distance will be the , and with no damping, it will remain constant. When released, the mass will oscillate.

Press the start arrow on the timer, and measure the time for 5 complete oscillations. Remember one oscillation means the mass starts at a point and returns to that same point. Record your amplitude and time values in Data Table E1.

Repeat Steps 1 and 2, keeping the 100 g mass and stretching the spring the same distance, keeping the amplitude constant. Record your amplitude and times in Data Table E1. As the mass is oscillating, note the activity of the energy bars to the left of the spring.
Use the left arrow on the mass indicator to set the mass value to 50 g.

Stretch the spring approximately 30 cm = 0.30 m from the equilibrium position. This distance will be the amplitude, and with no damping, it will remain constant. When released, the mass will oscillate.

Press the start arrow on the timer, and measure the time for 5 complete oscillations. Remember one oscillation means the mass starts at a point and returns to that same point. Record your amplitude and time values in Data Table E2.
Repeat Steps 5 and 6, keeping the 50 g mass and stretching the spring the same distance, keeping the amplitude constant. Record your amplitude and times in Data Table E2.
Use the right arrow on the mass indicator to set the mass value to 200 g. As the mass is oscillating, note the activity of the energy bars to the left of the spring.

Stretch the spring approximately 30 cm = 0.30 m from the equilibrium position. This distance will be the amplitude, and with no damping, it will remain constant. When released, the mass will oscillate.

Press the start arrow on the timer, and measure the time for 5 complete oscillations. Remember one oscillation means the mass starts at a point and returns to that same point. Record your amplitude and time values in Data Table E3.

Repeat Steps 9 and 10, keeping the 200 g mass and stretching the spring the same distance, keeping the amplitude constant. Record your amplitude and times in Data Table E3. As the mass is oscillating, note the activity of the energy bars to the left of the spring.
Determine the (time for one oscillation) T and for each of the trials and record these values in the appropriate location in Data Tables E1, E2, and E3.
Calculate the angular frequency, ω = 2πf, for each of the trials, and record these values in the appropriate location in Data Tables E1, E2, and E3. (Show one sample calculation.)
Calculate the average angular frequency, ω = 2πf, for each mass value, and record these values in the appropriate location in Data Tables E1, E2, and E3.
Using the average angular frequency, ω, and Equation 11, determine the spring constant k for each mass value. Record these values and your calculated average value in Data Table E4.

pageData.altText: Equation 11: Omega equals begin square root begin fraction k over m end fraction end square root

pageData.text: Use the data for the 100 g mass in Data Table E1 to calculate K (), U (potential energy) and E (total energy) at the points indicated on Data Table E5. Show your calculations, and record your values in Data Table E5.
Return the materials to equipment kit, and clean the area.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

text: Examine the data and percent error values in Data Table 2 where the mass of the pendulum bob increased but the angular displacement and length of the simple pendulum remained constant.  Describe whether or not your data shows that the period of the pendulum depends on the mass of the pendulum bob, to within a reasonable percent error.

Examine the data and percent error values in Data Table 3 where the angular displacement of the simple pendulum decreased but the mass of the pendulum bob and the length of the pendulum remained constant.  Describe whether or not your data shows that the period of the pendulum depends on the angular displacement of the pendulum bob, to within a reasonable percent error.

Examine the graph created using the data in Data Table 4 of the Period, T vs. √L. If the relationship is linear, what does the value of the slope of the line represent? Is your result within a reasonable percent error (<5%)? If not, explain why your result is not within a reasonable percent error.

From your examination of the graph created using the data in Data Table 4 of Period, T vs. √L, what would you determine is the relationship between the period of the pendulum and the length of the pendulum?

    If you used graphing software, upload the graph image rather than the spreadsheet file.
Click on the browse button to upload the file

text: Examine the slope of the line on the graph of T 2 vs L. The slope of the line is a constant containing the acceleration due to gravity, g. Using the slope of your line, determine the experimental value for g.
Compare the value you determined for g from the slope of the graph to the expected value of 9.81 m/s2 by calculating the percent error.

The measurements for the lab were made in a location with a constant acceleration of gravity. If the acceleration due to gravity was decreased (g < 9.81 m/s2), how would the values for the period of the pendulum change? Support your answer with equations.

text: E1. As you increased the mass on the spring, explain how this affected the period of the oscillation.  Review the data in Extension Activity Data Tables E1, E2, and E3.
E2. As you increased the mass on the spring, explain how this affected the frequency of the oscillation.  Review the data in Extension Activity Data Tables E1, E2, and E3.
E3. As you increased the mass on the spring, explain how this affected the amplitude of the oscillation.  Review the data in Extension Activity Data Tables E1, E2 and E3.

E4. Because you did not adjust the spring constant during the experiment, it should have remained constant, as evidenced by your data in Extension Activity Data Table E4.  Describe what would happen to the angular frequency of the oscillator if you increased the spring constant, k. Use the lab simulation to experiment with different values of k and use actual numbers to support your answer.
E5. Review your data in Extension Activity Data Table E5.  Was mechanical energy conserved? Explain why or why not.

A map of the procedural workflow of activity one of this investigation. To prepare, clear an area for the pendulum, measure the mass of washers and pendulum, assemble and hang the pendulum and measure its length. In activity 1, displace the pendulum by a given angle, record the pendulum swing and determine the time for 5 oscillations. Next, calculate the period of oscillation. Then, add a washer and repeat for 1-4 washers. Next, reset the pendulum, record its mass and displace the pendulum by the specified angle. Then, record the pendulum swing, determine the time for 5 oscillations and calculate the period of. Next, change the angle of displacement and repeat for all angles. Then, reset the pendulum, record the mass and displace the pendulum by the given angle. Next, record the pendulum swing, determine the time for 5 oscillations and calculate the period. Then, change the length of the pendulum and repeat for all lengths. Proceed to Activity 2.

A map of the procedural workflow for activity 2 and extension activity of this investigation. After completing activity 1, in activity 2, you will calculate the period of oscillation using the given equation, calculate the percent difference in periods and calculate the square root of L for the length trials.  Then, you will graph period versus square root of L. In the extension activity, you will open the PHET activity “Masses and Springs” and set up the spring with given conditions. Then, you will run the simulation and determine the time for 5 oscillations. Next, you will vary the conditions and repeat the trials for all of the given conditions. Then, you will calculate the period of the spring for each trial, the angular frequency, the average angular frequency and the spring constant. Finally, you will calculate the potential and kinetic energy of the spring that the given points.
Figure 4: a pendulum from equilibrium with the pivot, arm, and bob labeled, and a pendulum showing the angle relative to the pendulum at rest

data.title: Acceleration
data.content: The change in velocity with respect to time

data.title: Amplitude
data.content: The maxiumum displacement from the equilibrium position

data.title: Angular displacement
data.content: The angle in radians through which a point or line has been rotated

data.title: Angular velocity
data.content: The measure of the rotation rate

data.title: Displacement
data.content: The distance between two points; it is a vector quantity

data.title: Equilibrium position
data.content: The location where an object experiences no angular acceleration

data.title: Frequency
data.content: The reciprocal of the period; it measures the number oscillations per unit time

data.title: Friction
data.content: The resistance that one surface or object encounters when moving over another

data.title: Gravitational potential energy
data.content: The potential energy an object has due to a change in its position when it is present in a gravitational field

data.title: Hooke's law
data.content: States that the restoring force is proportional to the displacement

data.title: Kinetic energy
data.content: The energy which a body possesses by virtue of being in motion

data.title: Mechanical energy
data.content: All the energy an object has because of its motion and its position

data.title: Oscillatory motion
data.content: The back and forth motion of an object as it passes through an equilibrium or mean position

data.title: Period
data.content: The time it takes a simple pendulum mass to make one complete oscillation

data.title: Simple harmonic motion (SHM)
data.content: A special type of oscillatory motion in which displacement, velocity and acceleration vary with respect to time as either a sine or cosine function

data.title: Simple pendulum
data.content: A mass suspended from a light string that can oscillate when displaced from its rest position

data.title: Velocity
data.content: The rate of change of the position of an object that refers to both the speed and direction of an object; it is a vector quantity
